title: Opening Principles
description: Master the fundamental principles of chess openings

lessons.title: Control the Center
lessons.description: Make the best opening move to control the center

alternatives.feedback: Excellent! d4 is also a great central move, equally good as e4
Nf3 is a good developing move but doesn't control the center as directly
Edge pawns should generally not be moved early. Focus on center control

lessons.hint: Move a central pawn two squares forward
lessons.explanation: e4 controls the central squares d5 and f5, giving your pieces more space and better development opportunities. This is one of the most popular opening moves in chess.

lessons.title: Develop with Purpose
lessons.description: Develop a piece toward the center

alternatives.feedback: Bc4 is good but developing knights before bishops is generally preferred
Bringing the queen out early is dangerous and violates opening principles
This weakens your king position. Develop pieces instead

lessons.hint: Knights before bishops! Develop your kingside knight
lessons.explanation: Nf3 develops the knight to an active square, attacks the e5 pawn, and prepares castling. Knights are generally developed before bishops in the opening.

lessons.title: King Safety First

alternatives.feedback: The queen doesn't need to move yet. Focus on king safety
Pawn moves should wait. Castle your king first
While developing, castling is more urgent for king safety

lessons.hint: Castle kingside to put your king in a safe position
lessons.explanation: O-O (castling) moves the king to safety behind a wall of pawns and brings the rook into the game. King safety is a top priority in the opening.

lessons.title: Don't Move the Same Piece Twice
lessons.question: Which of these moves would be a mistake in the opening?

choices.feedback: Correct choice - develops a new piece to a good square
Good - develops the bishop while preparing to castle
Excellent - develops with tempo by attacking the knight
This violates the principle of not moving the same piece twice without good reason

lessons.explanation: Moving the bishop from c4 to b3 wastes time by moving the same piece twice. In the opening, it's better to develop new pieces rather than repositioning already developed ones.

lessons.title: Avoid Opening Traps
lessons.description: Don't fall for this common opening trap

alternatives.feedback: Ng4 looks tempting but allows a strong response with d4!
Nd5 is premature and allows Nxd5 followed by d4
You've already developed this knight. Don't move it again

lessons.hint: Develop your kingside bishop and prepare to castle
lessons.explanation: Be7 safely develops the bishop and prepares castling. Other knight moves like Ng4 allow White to gain tempo with d4, winning time in development.
